Definition: In this task, you will receive a public commentary from online platforms. You are expected to divide the commentary into two classes: obscene and non-obscene. Obscenity refers to material and acts of pornography that violate the public's sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Guess Barron needs to babysit the dummy and supervise his tweets.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated to pornography or obscenity.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Sailors found whores and coke.I'm shocked!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: I appreciate your hopes, but the fact is LTD's ridership has declined.  

According to the US Census American Community Survey, use of LTD in the Eugene/Springfield metro area has fallen from 3.6% of commuters in 2014 to 2.4% in 2016.  

The ridership of the Pioneer Parkway/River Bend is only used to 7% of it's capacity, which represents a HUGE carbon footprint to transport just a few people.  
http://csaplanning.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/GatewayEMXperformancereview_webversion_2.pdf
(This is the performance of the Pioneer Parkway EmX. Page 14 says, "it appears that actual utilization is less than 7%".)

LTD has spent well over $100 million on a more expensive but less efficient EmX transit.

Comment: "Often a high-ranking source cannot go on the record because the info is classified. To reveal one's identity could be a career-ending move, or even result in prosecution. But it serves the greater good."

You have no idea whether it serves the greater good or not. It depends on the motive of the person revealing the information, and that's impossible to know without knowing who it is. Surely you don't think that everyone who anonymously leaks supposedly classified information does so altruistically?

The US government's massive surveillance program was revealed by Edward Snowden. He went public. And in doing so he revealed exactly who he was and why he did it. That's why his information is so credible, even though we don't have direct evidence of what his information revealed.

Comment: There will not be a book published this fall more urgent, important, or controversial than The Dangerous Case of Donald Trump, the work of 27 psychiatrists, psychologists and mental health experts to assess President Trump’s mental health.
They had come together last March at a conference at Yale University to wrestle with two questions.
One was on countless minds across the country: “What’s wrong with him?”
The second was directed to their own code of ethics: “Does Professional Responsibility Include a Duty to Warn” if they conclude the president to be dangerously unfit?
Their decision: “We respect the rule, we deem it subordinate to the single most important principle that guides our professional conduct: that we hold our responsibility to human life and well-being as paramount.”
Hence, this profound, illuminating and discomforting book undertaken as “a duty to warn.”

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: This is a well-researched study used a variety of information gathering instruments to develop a variety of options for improving downtown. Some below are summarizing it as reaffirming what we already know and more specifically, as vindication that they - the smartypants of the community - have the answers if only our elected leaders would have listened to them.
Skimming the report and reading the RG summary it is apparent that the study authors offer perspective, having done similar studies of other downtown areas that have overcome the challenge of homelessness. One identified issue is that the problem is "concentrated in a small area" instead of being diffused like most cities. While we've kicked the homeless out from the riverbank, from under bridges, and from Springfield, they've come downtown to seek their "fortunes". Kick them out from downtown and they'll return to the river and elsewhere.
Homelessness is not about bad seeds. It's about our priorities.

Comment: An award for courage under pressures we'll never know, for leadership, and for talent. Congratulations. And did I say for courage? 

Folks in the future will ask, "You mean Tom Fox's search for truth wasn't always accepted and supported by the Church hierarchy, even though he was often prophetic?"   

Consider: Bishop John England, for whom the award is named, in 1822 USA  defended the separation of Church and state. My kids today say, "Duh!" But in Bishop England's day that concept was not only risky for any Catholic, it--along with a free press and other heresies of "Americanism" --was declared gravely sinful, disloyal, and heretical. 

Truth, as Tom says, is a Catholic journalist's sacred mission, even when--especially when-- aggressively seeking it is declared un-Catholic and, yes, literally sinful. May truth always be OUR mission as well.  And may we always celebrate a Fox-NCR virtue often solely ascribed to the Catholic Right: "Contemporary Courage to be Authentically Catholic."

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

I hope JT has a sense of humour.

Comment: Ken,

Would you please explain how a person who choses not to cast a ballot still "counts".  If one doesn't make their wishes known, then they do not influence the outcome.  Not including withheld votes in the outcome is only logical and those who made this choice lose all influence they would have had on the election outcome.  It is by no means a slap in the face to ignore those who will not take a stand when determining an election outcome.  Out of the many choices available on most ballots, surely one can come to some kind of decision.

Your reckoned 9 million Canadians who chose, and I stress – chose-,  not to vote actually did make a choice to accept the election outcome based on the expressed will of others, rather than to make a decision themselves.  Sometimes decisions are hard, sometimes you can't get all you want, but with our Canadian electoral system if you don't make your own choice, someone else will choose for you.

What David Black has done is a tragedy.

Comment: Adding in, again, a piece from the past, and then asking a question from that: In 2006 the City Council made a decision to change the routing of the rail to take the train through the airport than through Salt Lake. The newspaper of record at the time wrote this as part of the reasoning for this decision:

While adding $200 million to the $3.9 billion construction, the airport route would average an estimated 95,000 passengers a day, while the Salt Lake route would carry 88,000. The airport route would be useful to employees commuting to the airport and Pearl Harbor Naval Base

“;The higher cost of the airport alternative would be offset by the higher ridership and user benefits for that alternative,”; the environmental statement says. 

So my question, even if you adjust the numbers because your cutting out half the line, wouldn't the system still be viable for the time being at least from those employees that work at the airport and JBPHH?

Comment: Your perspective is based on the assumption that FWPS hasn't been keeping up with the maintenance. Most school districts do a fantastic job in maintaining their buildings, especially considering restraint budgets & the amount of people that occupy our schools on a daily basis. What if you have hundreds of people walking, sitting, working & eating in your home every day for the last 40 -50 years? Do you think you might need to replace a few things -- couple pieces of furniture, maybe a kitchen remodel or two? Maybe you might renovate or even move? Not to mention, schools should be preparing students for working in this century, not the past. Take a look at your phone -- do you still use a rotary phone or party line?  Still use that formal living room as much as you did when you bought that house? FWPS is trying to give our students the opportunity to learn next-generation skills, and they can't do it in an old 1950's formal living room. Heavy-duty wear-n-tear means heavy-duty solutions.

Comment: Under ObamaCare, we "insure" too much.  A $30 birth control prescription requires a doctor visit every six months ... unnecessary expense.  The doctor has to file a claim form, and has to employ a staff that has to sort through 10,000 different codes for every imaginable product or procedure, and for dozens of different insurance companies who all have their own codes.  His staff as to keep records and follow up on receipts of payment, and refile when they aren't paid.  The pharmacy has to do the same thing.  As do each of the insurance companies.  And it takes the same number of man-hours to process a $30 claim as a $30,000 claim, so this $30 claim adds about $300 of costs to the system.  That's why costs are rising.

A lot of people would lose their jobs if we went to a national HSA program, so we have to decide what we want: cheaper health care, or an inefficient jobs program?  You get a lot of propaganda opposing HSAs because they'll cost jobs and insurance company profits.

Comment: Not at all true.  Let me explain 'law' a bit.

Canadian law, based as it is on British law, is largely composed of judge-made law.  This is true whether it's pure common law (with no legislative basis) or judge-made law providing depth to often bare-bones legislation.  

Statutes can't possibly set out every situation and eventuality to which they apply; that's where judges come in. They've been doing it for close to 1,000 years now.

This particular case is about a General production order in the Criminal Code, and its exemption for "information that is privileged or otherwise protected from disclosure by law."

To be specific - journalist privilege (mostly a judge-made concept) and the extent to which section 2 (b) of the Charter is involved - "freedom of the press."

The Court of Appeal decision mostly involved prior court decisions.

So, yes, it's up to the Supreme Court to clarify the law. As courts have been doing for centuries.

Comment: Nonsense, another poster with a sanitised version of history. The problem with your assertion is that there was somehow a native way of life which stood in contrast with European society. There were thousands of very different native tribes, empires, regions, theocracies, kingdoms, fiefdoms, confederacies, etc in America prior to European arrival. Some were conquering, some built massive structures and large infrastructure works , others were nomadic. Many affected their environment and controlled it, changing local climates, deforestation, etc others did not. Most adapted to new technologies, whether horses or guns, etc, and modified their societies accordingly. Sadly, what they couldn't fight was germs and diseas, which wiped 90% of them out.

But to suggest their innovations and culture don't live on is silly. Plant domestication (corn, peppers, squash, tomtato, potato, etc), farming techniques , canoes/Kayaks, survival in the artic, modern constitutions, urban planning ideas, etc.

Comment: Finish the rail means we must build rail all the way to UH at a minimum. Do it right means we need to manage the costs and schedule but must also recognize that building it cheapest and fastest isn't always the smartest or most efficient thing to do over the long term. 

Costs can me amortized and recovered over decades or even generations. The continual focus on cost right now, is short sighted. It's more important to maximize utility, quality, and aesthetics which all have direct long term impacts on quality of life. And quality of life is really what we should be optimizing, not dollars. 

I agree project management has been subpar up to this point and needs to be vastly improved. However it is important to keep the proper perspective. We are only 1% into the lifetime of the rail project. We have a long way to go and there is still plenty of time to do better. We should not be re-litigating the decision to build it at every bump in the road

Comment: I'm a little confused that Mr. Bozievich as "starred" this comment.  It implies he's opposed to the ban.  Yet, I believe he's one of the Commissioners who led the action for the County Board to support raising the age for purchasing and using tobacco products to twenty-one.  That change would be far more restrictive than banning smoking and vaping in County parks.  

Personally, I favor both restrictions.  I find smoking a very unpleasant, intrusive behavior if it's done in the presence of others.  I avoid areas where persons are smoking.  If the County wants to establish "smoking areaa" in the parks,....fine.  However, as the City of Eugene has, I think, found, smokers often "take over" areas such as parks and others don't have the opportunity to enjoy them.  

Outsider supports "personal freedom".....great, so do I.  However, the freedom to use a public space w/o breathing someone's cigarette as second-hand smoke is a personal freedom too. One which I feel trumps freedom to smoke.

Comment: Section 15. Alaska Permanent Fund

"At least twenty-five percent of all mineral lease rentals, royalties, royalty sale proceeds, federal mineral revenue sharing payments and bonuses received by the State shall be placed in a permanent fund the principal of which shall be used only for those income-producing investments specifically designated by law as eligible for permanent fund investments. All income from the permanent fund shall be deposited in the general fund unless otherwise provided by law.

A constitutional amendment in 1976 added this entire section. It mandates the creation of the Alaska Permanent Fund. The law on the matter provides that approximately half of the annual income of the fund is to be distributed on a per capita basis (the dividend program) and as much of the balance as necessary is to be deposited to the corpus (principal) of the fund to account for losses in the value of the fund due to inflation".

Comment: As much of the debate in the Charlie Gard case this journalist is either ill informed or choosing to ignore most of the facts.
The world renowned children's hospital considered giving Charlie the experimental treatment. 
 in January on the chance it might help.. He began having seizures and it was the brain damage resulting in those seizures that caused the hospital to decide not to go ahead. Any funds the parents raised privately for transfer to the US were not available for three months after that.
Many top doctors, from other hospitals and countries, consulted on this case, the parents appointed their own independent consultant, they all concurred that the treatment would not benefit the child.
The parents did not give 'informed consent' to using Charlie for experimental purposes.  They insisted to the end that this was a treatment that would make Charlie a 'normal little boy'
Charlie was given the best available, without concern for costs.  In the UK we do not experiment on babies.

The idea is to connect the high tech sector of waterloo, with that of toronto... but to also connect the more manufacturing and rising tech sector of london. We all know the fucking via train sucks from london to toronto. It takes forever, is probably comparable to flying in price, and you can drive there faster. This is a project that could potentially revitalize the niagara peninsula and take a lot of traffic off the 401.

Comment: For a reasonably-talented person with a few common tools and some high-grade steel scrap to produce a 'lightning link' (a simple sear-tripping device), almost nothing.  For the individual factory parts necessary to make such a conversion (parts that will NOT work in an unmodified semi-auto receiver), a few dollars.  For the precision mill necessary to convert a semi-auto receiver to one capable of taking regular factory full-auto/select-fire parts, considerably more.
    For making, or for possessing, an unlicensed (no Federally-approved application, no tax stamp) sear-trip device:  A decade in prison.  For possessing unlicensed specific full-auto components (that cannot be legally purchased without Federal approval):  A decade in prison.  For making or possessing an unlicensed fully-machined receiver capable of taking full-auto components:  A decade in prison.  Plus $250,000 in fines for each offense. 
     Stealing a truck is far cheaper.

In sum if Trump stays the course we could see an economic renaissance and a low weaning off of public spending since  2008.

Comment: Aggregate isn't the proper measurement.  Taxable basis per capita is the correct comparison because we are talking about funding per student.
Property valuations per capita are higher in the urban areas than rural areas, but that is only one piece of the tax pie.  For example the taxable value for Oil&Gas in Weld county is $9.2B in addition to property valuations.  Garfield County is $3.4B.  Even Yuma County with a whopping 10K people has a taxable O&G value of $240M, which would equate to $23K/person of taxable value.  Denver is zero.  Personal property is often used as an indicator for sales tax revenue.  Denver is $23,100/person, Yuma is $23,600, Weld is $34,900.  So from a personal property standpoint Denver citizens are poorer than even Yuma citizens. 
You should challenge your urban-centric paradigm a little bit more by really visiting other parts of Colorado (not just driving through).  There are economically depressed rural areas and thriving rural areas, just like in cities.

Comment: In neither answer was the matter of how the individual obtained information on someone else's pay addressed.   This is significant as there may be a privacy violation. It is certainly appropriate for an employee to inquire about his or her pay, but it is absolutely inappropriate to reference the pay of a specific individual unless this information is in the public domain.    Further, length of experience is only one consideration in determining salary.  What about education and performance?  Two people can do the same job and one just happens to perform better.  With respect to market research around pay, companies typically do this and measure themselves against an appropriate peer group of comparable organizations.  Often this is conducted through a third party.  Certainly, an individual can do some checking but the data is only as reliable as the source.  
G & M, it would probably be a good idea to vet information provided in the answers in this column sometimes.

Comment: Wow, is this for real? I can only assume this is an article funded by animal agriculture. First of all, I've never met anyone who thought "plant-based diet" meant anything other than vegan...and I've been using that term for 10 years. It's only distinguished from vegan because vegans avoid animal exploitation in all aspects of life, whereas "plant-based" eaters might still wear leather and fur or still use products tested on animals. But honestly, more absurd than the misinterpretation of those words is the assertion than any kind of animal-sourced dairy is "healthy" (as though for some reason ice cream is unhealthy, but bleu cheese is great for the body!). Comment: A web site is like any other machine that is used by a company to do business, it requires regular maintenance and has a limited useful lifespan. If you had a company car you would buy the newest one you could afford and would put some time and money into its maintenance. A website is no different.

Looking at your website and the software being used to operate it I see two issues that should be dealt with urgently: 1. the version of the web server (Apache/2.2.15) is very old (released in March 2010) and 2: the version of PHP in which the site was written (PHP/5.3.3) is also very old (released in July 2010). Both are no longer supported by their respective open-source communities and have numerous bugs that have been fixed in subsequent releases. If you have someone responsible for keeping the site updated then they are not doing their job; if there is nobody maintaining the site then you need to find someone to do it.

Make sure you will not have these issues with your new site.

Comment: I can't speak to the specific case because I don't know enough about his situation. Retired on highly inadequate Social Security, I get around $140 a month in food stamps, which doesn't last the month. I'm fortunate that I live in subsidized housing so my rent is low, around 30 percent of income, so I get by as long as I'm careful. The need in Eugene for subsidized housing is much greater than the supply. 

Everyone's situation is different. The amount of food stamps you get is based on your income and other considerations such as how many people you're supporting. 

Nationally, food stamp amounts are inadequate. especially for people with kids, and do not last the month. The states run the program, and a lot of them are very restrictive. A whole lot of people in this country are struggling just to survive. To get the picture from the inside, I recommend the book "Hand to Mouth: Living in Bootstrap America" by Linda Tirado. I've also seen some good documentaries on Netflix.

Comment: In the mid- to late 1930s France had the largest and most powerful army in the world, yet they failed to act against the fledgling German army when it violated the Versailles treaty and occupied the Rhineland. The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: While driving 80 does save time, the reverse of it it reduces a car's mpg. Vehicle wind resistance for the majority of cars increases the faster you go, decreasing mpg.

This site lets you compute how much your mpg will drop by going faster. For my 30 mpg car, driving 80 mph reduces mpg by 28%. Meaning I'm buying more gas to go the same distance at 80 mph versus 65 mph. Not worth it.

I'll be the car on the right going 65 mph while everyone else blows by me wasting gas. Aloha.

Comment: I don't think this discussion is well served by calling people murderers or shills. The fact is, we humans are all complicit in human-caused climate change. That's a fact. But the point I was trying to make is, what are we going to do about it? I believe using children in a lawsuit against President Obama is a waste of taxpayer money and it looks like a PR stunt for Olson to gain publicity and notoriety for herself and to raise her professional profile. It achieves nothing in terms of reducing emissions. In fact, the Paris accord that Obama entered the U.S into and the recent negotiations on climate change he conducted with China (the two countries are the biggest sources of emissions) will do far more good. We need actual solutions, and many environmental groups have long been involved in getting those solutions and they are making substantive progress, in my opinion, which should not be discounted or scoffed at.

Comment: The reason why we face a problem of antibiotic resistant bacteria has nothing to do with the likes of Caulfield. Many people insist that their doctors give them a prescription even when one is not called for, such as for a viral infection. These people will simply go from doctor to doctor until they find one that will give them the prescription. Even when the prescription is valid, many people do not take the full course of the antibiotic, stopping when they feel better. This leaves strong bacteria unaffected and strengthens the strain. 

Many reputable doctors, scientists, and public policy experts have been warning of over-prescription and misuse of antibiotics for years.

Comment: The cops show up in half an hour -- your stuff is gone and maybe you're dead. Cops have no constitutional requirement to stop a crime in progress. They aren't even required to investigate the theft after it happens.

This is what I learned doing prison ministry. Burglars who hit a house during the day generally have no plans to kill anyone and often are not armed (but sometimes are). Burglars who hit a house at night are prepared to kill to get what they want.

So, yeah, I would defend my house and my family. I would call 911, but what happens between that phone call and the cops arriving would depend entirely on the actions of the burglar. Leave my stuff where you found it or else.

And the fact is, too many parents lack the skills to be good parents and do not or have not learned from their own parents how important it is to show one's love to one's children. Many children who lack this turn to bad behavior such as bullying and grow up with problems that lead to incarceration. We need to begin in the schools and Mr. Rod is showing why we need to start there. If the parents do not give their children this love, where else can they receive the love and discipline? It takes love for proper disciplining. Without love, disciplining only results in resentment and acting out. When will our schools learn this?

Comment: What you're forgetting is the benefits provided by an employer (cheaper insurance) is part of the compensation provided for working there. It's not some freebee - it's part of your salary and the employer has agreed to pay it. And the savings you decry, are discounts given to the employer by the insurer for having a large plan with many participants. small plans cost more to administer and thus come at a higher cost. So no - just because some people are paying higher premiums due to being in a smaller plan, that doesn't equate to subsidizing anybody. If anybody is being subsidized, it's the people who pay nothing to use the same system the rest of us are paying for.

Comment: IMO, there is nothing wrong with ambiguity - it is room for the Holy Spirit to guide us in walking with each other. Jesus did not say come to me and I will give you rules so you can tell others how to live and answers so you can tell others what to think. He said, "I will send the Holy Spirit who will teach you to observe everything I have commanded", which is what is happening these days in the widespread questioning. Uncertainty, doubt, questioning, chaos are not bad. They are opportunities to grow and make choices.

When we have all the answers how people should live their lives and what they should think or believe, there is no need for faith or the Spirit. IMO belief, in the sense of living trust in Jesus and the Spirit, is a personal matter as we journey on and write our story. It cannot be dictated by others who know neither our journey or our story. We can walk with each other without demanding that they come around to our way of thinking.

Comment: It's difficult to know the details of what causes so man doctors to leave and why it is difficult to staff enough in Florence. To say there is a national shortage is to say pistachios are expensive because they are expensive everywhere. There are a few things we do know.
There IS money in our medical system. One recent example is the large return for investors: "Agate Resources insiders made $34 million on sale of company that used public funds to provide health care to low-income Oregonians." 
Doctors can make good money, but the real money is in specialization. New doctors face huge student loan payments, so specialization helps pay those debts more quickly. 
Capitalistic competition among care providers is not working. When one is sick, one does not want to "buy he cheapest" care out of fear that you get what you pay for (even if that is wrong). What competition is there in Florence? And how can one "shop" as an informed consumer in the medical field? Choice is an illusion.

Comment: That is surprising that the deaths did NOT occur in the condo that originated the fire.  Next question is how can a fire spread so fast and intensely in a building made of concrete?  The other point is instead of installing fire sprinklers in each condo which in 2017 prices, could approach $12,000 for each condo owner, how about a partial sprinkler system in which there is a sprinkler system ONLY in the common walkways of these type of older condos & the sprinkler systems do not extend into each individual condo.  Marco Polo, like Waipuna, are open air type common walkways on each floor & it should not be that difficult nor expensive to run water pipes up the side of one building and then run the sprinkler pipes only in these common area walkways.  Had this type of partial sprinkler system been installed, the common walkways areas would have remained clear of smoke, fire and destroyed only the condo in which the fire originated and not nearby condos on the same or upper floors....

Comment: Corporations and governments are fundamentally different organiztions.  The primary objective of a corporation is to make as much money as possible, often in the face of competition. The primary objective of a (federal) government is to ensure the survival and propsperity of the country, and there is no domestic competition for the government to contend with (though there are elections).  Both types of organizations depend on the people (market) to survive.  With corporations, the people can easily choose between companies (e.g. McDonalds vs. Burger King) but they have little direct influence over who works at those companies.  With governments, the people directly elect key people in the government, but have little direct influence over the type of government, which for the most part is established in the constitution and is only changed slowly over time through reforms.

In my opinion, the management styles for thes two types of organziations are very incongruent.

Comment: I think one of the problems with the additional Growlers is that this is a Navy base and not a commercial airport.  At a commercial airport there are defined flight patterns so that folks can make an informed decision.  I moved here almost a decade ago and thought I had a good grasp of the flight patterns.  But this year the Navy has thrown a curve ball and many more flights are going directly over the neighborhood than in the past (except for the year OLF was shut down).  

And since they are military - security dictates they will not tell you where they fly.  Add another near 50% Growler flights and that may be the breaking point for me staying or leaving this island.  

Somebody made the point that ALL the Growlers would be in one location....does that make sound strategic sense?  It may make financial sense for Island County, but for the safety of the country?  Not so sure....

Comment: I agree about the obsession part. Would Oregon stand for the player-related scandals so many top programs routinely have? From the basketball alleged assaults of a few years ago, I think the answer is clear.
Can a top program also not sell its soul? Stanford shows its possible, as well as several others.
Helfrich is in a tough spot: the offense no longer is elite, it's just one of many that play up tempo and zone read. The surprise and conditioning, so critical to the Kelly era, are gone or no longer unique. And the D performance is keyed on stopping the other team from matching the Ducks quick scoring; all the previous Ds had to do was stop one or two drives and then the floodgates opened.
It's now obvious that the Ducks succeeded in the past with below top-level players, across the board (check the NFL draft overall, compared to an AL or Ohio St). Helf and Co. are, if anything, now faring worse in recruiting because of the downslide. 
Hey, it was a great ride!

Comment: I don't see the point of the DREAM program, honestly.  It doesn't grant any special way to become a citizen. What is the point of temporarily residing in a country that you are not a citizen of, becoming educated there, only to have to leave (or stay illegally, and not be able to work) when you turn 35.  To me, it seems better to find a way to wind down the DREAM program. Those with no current education commitments, have 1 year to either attain citizenship or leave. Those currently in college, have what is left of their 4-year degree program (max) to finish their education and attain citizenship, or leave at the end. They are not without a country, they have a citizenship - albeit one somewhat unfamiliar to them.  DREAM Act just creates a purgatory of people, who think that they have some claim on the US just due to having been here for a while, where they really have no claim.

Comment: Ms. Patkotak, thank you for this important column. I also agree that the overwhelming majority of people in this country are good, decent, hardworking people who are not themselves bigoted. The problem, however, is not individual racism but institutional racism. When the levers of power are predominantly accessible to select classes of Americans -- and denied to others -- discriminatory practices are built into the very structure of that society. What we saw in the election of Donald Trump was a panicked grab for those levers by a class of Americans who not only feels their grip slipping, but also spies those "other" classes coming up fast. This is what the "Again" in MAGA is all about. The vehemence with which some commenters on this thread deny that fact is proof of the primacy of institutional norms to guide individual behavior, even for otherwise good, decent, hardworking people.

Comment: Most  of  the  issues  dealing  with  First  Nations  seems  to  revolve  around  the  question  of  who  controls  the  land  and  what  happens  on  it?

In  Canada  this  question  is  confused  by  the  very  different  status  of  treaties  in  different  areas.  In  most  of  BC  formal  treaties  were  never  signed  and  there  are  valid  questions  about  whether  aboriginal  rights  were  ever  surrendered.  This  is  further  confused  by  overlapping  land  claims  by  different  FN  groups.

In the advent of Christ, symbolic and dietary laws are like GPS - when you arrive at your destination, following the GPS directions is completely useless.  However, God's morality never changed and the moral foundation of the Mosaic Law still applies.  Children should not dishonor their parents yet Christians have no Biblical obligation or even right to stone their children to death.  Bestiality and homosexual practice are still sinful and yet no Christian is obligated to or justified by the Bible to kill homosexual or bestiality practitioners.

Comment: My perpetual answer to statements such as Mr. Flanagan's "...disbar parties from making definite-sounding campaign promises..." is to refer to the Ontario Superior Court of Justice ruling on the Canadian Taxpayer's Federation v. The Government of Ontario regarding Dalton McGuity's written promise not to raise taxes if elected.  You can get it here:  http://www.taxpayer.com/media/73.pdf

In short, the Court ruled that no one may be held to a pre-election promise should they eventually form government.  Something about a concept of not thwarting the will of Parliament.

So, thank you Dalton, thank you so very much for bringing out in the open and making it official that ANYTHING said by an aspiring politician during an election campaign has NO LEGAL FORCE, let alone moral obligation.  I would urge every Canadian voter to remember this whenever an election comes nigh.

I know it's hard for folks "up there" to remember that Alaska is a huge state made up of more areas then Anchorage, Fairbanks, Palmer, Kenai, Matsu and the rest of points North. 
There exists a beautiful green area of Alaska where massive cedars, spruce, hemlock and pine grow next to alder. It is a temperate rain forest where fishing, mining, limited logging, and now tourism. Over a million cruise ship passengers visited this year.  
There are several ship building businesses located through out Southeast, the largest being the Vigor Ship yard in Ketchikan.
Most of SE or the Panhandle is comprised of islands with villages, there are three International airports, ferry terminals, docks to accommodate super large cruise ships, numerous air taxi companies that provide transportation between the islands (villages and towns) + roads. It is fortunate to have the USCG here, bases in Ketchikan, Sitka and Juneau. The US Navy submarines visit and NOAA 's vessel as well.

SOURCE: State of Hawaii, Department of Taxation Refundable Food/Excise Tax Credit Form N-311 (Rev. 2016)

Comment: Ducks played awful in the first half, much better in the second half. Not sure why they've look so bad on these two road-game losses, but they need to figure it out. Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: They focus on demand because it is the CAUSATIVE part of the equation.

 A city in Canada CANNOT get, on the backs of local workers, to house prices that are dozens of times the average annual local income. Banks do not fork out mortgages for dozens of times your income, and so, looking at the bell curve of incomes of local workers, your supply side conclusion makes no sense. None. A  huge external source of money is required to get prices that high. For Vancouver that money came mainly from Hong Kong and mainland China. For Toronto it comes from those places and others.

Go read the article today about the pre-selling of new Vancouver housing to rich overseas buyers: The quoted and experienced real estate spokesperson admits that "the demand is unlimited".

Comment: "Coloured" describes brown-skinned people. So why not just say "brown" like "white" and "black"? All races have some colour pigmentation, except perhaps Albinos, so "coloured" includes all races. People from, say, the Mediterranean are olive complected, ie "coloured", but they're called "white". 
In South Africa, coloured is a political but inaccurate term to describe brown and people of mixed race. (In America it was eschewed for "African American", an American curiosity where people are fixated on where their ancestors originated, eg Irish-American, Italian-American, etc rather than simply "American".) People classified coloured are as fair as whites, olive as some Greeks or dark as blacks and everything in between. "Mixed-race" is not accurate either, except for first generation children of mixed-race parents but at a pinch it will do because that's how it started. Note in SA today the races are still mixing, so one day the majority of the population may be mixed race.

Comment: Part 1

A few decades before Jesus was born, two rabbis, Hillel and Shammai, debated Deuteronomy 24. Hillel noted the text said a man could divorce his wife for "a cause of sexual immorality." Since rabbis believed that every word in Scripture was there for a reason, Hillel decided that this word "cause" must refer to other grounds for divorce besides sexual immorality. Hillel believed a man could leave his wife for any reason: wearing her hair unbound or burning the toast.

Shammai, on the other hand, thought that Deuteronmy 24 only referred to sexual immorality, and that this "any cause" divorce was wrong.

Hillel's "any cause" divorce was popular among Jewish men. It was much easier to get, though more expensive. It is almost certainly what Joseph was thinking of when he considered divorcing Mary "quietly" in Matthew 1:19.

Comment: The federal government estimated methane emissions at 15% of all Canadian GHG emissions in 2013. Since then, many reports says that the level of  methane emissions in Canada has been underestimated. But even at 15%, the level of methane emissions in Canada is very worrying. Methane emissions have an enhanced effect on climate change because methane has a "climate forcing effect" 25 times grater on a 100 year basis than CO2 (72 times grater on a 20 year basis).
Methane emissions from the oil and gas industries are the largest anthropogenic sources of Canadian CH4 emissions, according to Canada's latest submission to the UNFCCC in April 2016. 
Production of crude oil in the Alberta bitumen oil sands is a major source of CH4 emissions as more and more natural gas is used to extract and process bitumen. It is estimated that around 20% of all the natural gas extracted in Canada goes to process bitumen. Most of this gas is "fracked gas" which is in itself a large source of CH4 emissions.

Comment: While there is no doubt that there are a substantial number of folks in the hospital who could just as well be in a far less secure setting for treament, your comment is very misleading.

Back in 2008 when the planning was being done for the new hospital facility in Salem and for the eventual facility in Junction City, the Department of Human services had funding for either 4 or 5 (I forget which) 60-bed, lower-security facilities to be sited around the state. The problem was that the NIMBY pushback was so fierce that only one was ever built, and that only after lengthy, extensive, expensive litigation. One attempt to site such a facility in an Eastern Oregon community resulted in the sheriff and district attorney being run out of town for supporting the idea. At that time I was tasked by the governor to draft a siting statute for these facilities much like the prison  sighting legislation in Oregon  that does does not allow the NIMBY effect to stop construction. The bill was DOA.

Comment: My understanding is that every lawyer in Canada is required to pay for and carry professional liability insurance that protects clients in the event the lawyer is found to be professionally negligent in a service they provide a client.  In the event a lawyer is criminally fraudulent and steals from a client, I don't believe the insurance protects the client.  As a self-regulated profession, in the event of criminal theft,  it is the lawyers of the Province who collectively band together and repay the harmed clients out of their own law society fees.  The $120k levy that the Law Society has placed on Mr. Beaver to compensate it for the costs of the investigation and disbarment, I believe he will have to pay that personally (and I expect he will not ever be allowed to practice again until it and possibly the other funds to compensate the harmed) are repaid to the Law Society.

Comment: I did some commercial halibut fishing in the late 1970s and would occasionally anchor in Port Chatham (an uninhabited bay 15 or 20 miles south of Seldovia).  It was one of the most beautiful places I'd ever seen - I really loved anchoring there.  10 or 15 years later I visited Port Chatham again, and was devastated to see the surrounding slopes had been clear cut.  I heard that the native corporation had sold the timber, which had been cut down and shipped as round logs to Japan.  I would 100 times rather see dozens of people a day hiking those trails, caring about them and fighting to protect them than to see no one visit, no one care and no one protect them.  Thanks for your work, Erin.

Comment: A number of people are equating Confederate soldiers to Nazi Germans. They note as well that memorials to the Nazis aren't permitted in Germany. However, there are no memorials commemorating slavery in the USA, either. However, in both Germany and America there are memorials to the people who fought in wars. Germany, has many of them, including memorials to German soldiers who fought for the Nazis in WWII.

Nazism and slavery are both repugnant ideologies. But commemorating soldiers who fought in wars under those ideologies is normal practice. It's not the ideology that's being memorialized. What's being memorialized is sacrifice, heroism, service and loyalty to a country.

Comment: Looking for solutions2--  While I found nothing  to confirm Joseph Lane was ever a slave holder, I did find some extraordinarily interesting material on Lane for which I am enthusiastically grateful to you.  As I have no time at the moment to digest all this, I'll be very brief:
First, that Oregonian opinion piece with the link here does claim Lane was a slave owner and cites  several sources to back him up, such as the Oregon Encyclopedia and Wikipedia.  However, I can find NO place where they  actually state Lane was a slave owner.  

However, there is a reference to the idea that some have claimed Peter Waldo, a young black man who lived with him on his ranch was a slave.  This linked to a fantastic source, truwe/tina, on Southern Oregon History.  This has an incredibly extensive list of historic  items on the complex relationship between Lane and Waldo, much of which was new to me.
Thanks again LFS2, you've given me much to ponder.

Comment: "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."

Article 1 Section 8 clauses 12 through 16 of the Constitution inform the 2nd amendment. Thus based on the text as a whole, one can reasonably posit that the point of the 2nd is that the "people" are the Militia and as such, had the right to keep and bear their own arms for the purpose of serving the Militia. In other words, you have the right to bear arms in service of the militia. So yes there are "ifs"

Fear not, the SCOTUS has affirmed your right as an individual (who is not a member of the militia since there is none) to own SOME arms.

She looked really tired, one could see she spent days crying and she looked like she had even lost weight. She said she had not been able to eat since breaking up with her boyfriend. Two weeks later, she called me and said that there is this single guy (never been married) who she knew from her old neighborhood and renewed contact on Facebook. Comment: How about the bringing back the idea of building a tunnel under Pearl Harbor and/or flyover along Nimitz Highway.   It doesn't look that expensive anymore... plus highway projects/improvements get more federal funding.
From The Advertiser in 2005: 
"John Emmerson, a civil engineer with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and a part-time aide to Cabanilla, said after the meeting that it would cost about $170 million to build a tunnel between Iroquois Point and Hickam, a distance of about 3,000 feet. With an estimated 9,000 vehicles moving through the tunnel during a peak traffic hour"
Scott Ishikawa, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation, said the agency is willing to look at the proposal but warned that DOT engineers believe the cost would be extremely high, as much as $500 million a mile, because of the sandy and muddy nature of the earth beneath the harbor. "The way the engineers described it, it would be like putting pylons on cream of mushroom soup," he said.

Comment: 2. Both Matthew and Luke shape their respective images of Jesus to distance him from the allegation that he was, in fact, a rebel, and also seek to clarify the relationship between Jesus and John. By the time Luke-Acts is written, there is a "standard" portrayal of Jesus as an exclusively spiritual Messiah who was misunderstood by -- everyone. But there remains this persistent tradition visible within the gospels in which both men are followed by militants, both men die accused of or associated with rebellion, and both men remain more or less enigmatic figures for at least several centuries.

Please understand: I am not prepared to argue that Jesus was, in fact, a Zealot or something of the kind. The Synoptic evangelists (especially Matthew) would have had a vested interest in portraying Jesus as having fulfilled the requirements for a Messiah, and would have had to walk a fine line between myth and reality.

Comment: Thanks to Bishop Braxton for this great article on the museum --I'm inspired to visit it!  I'm wondering why he doesn't mention St. Katharine Drexel in paragraph 15.  She founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament in 1891 and opened many schools in the South specifically for the African-American population because they weren't accepted in the public schools.    Their schools peppered the east coast cities of New York, Philadelphia, Newark, Atlanta, Boston, and more, as well as the Midwest -- Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland, Cincinnati, and Columbus. The Sisters also established Xavier University in New Orleans, a very prominent institution of the city, which is still in existence. St. Katharine Drexel was canonized in 2000 and her feast day is celebrated March 3.

Comment: There is one reason why 99.2% of all Canadian crude oil exports goes to the U.S.:  NOBODY ELSE AROUND THE WORLD WANTS IT!. Canadian oil producers have the capacity to export to other countries using U.S. port facilities, and they did it in 2014 (The Globe and Mail, Nov. 02, 2014 :" Oil sands crude reaching Europe, Asia"). Around 1.2 million barrels in "total" were shipped to refineries in Europe and Asia in July and August 2014. That same year,  Canadian crude oil exports to the U.S. averaged 3.5 million barrels "per day".  With the price differential between Brent and the TWI  at its highest, 2014 should have been the best opportunity for Canadian crude oil producers to make it on the international market. It didn't happen. That is why when the CAPP and the politicians argue that we need more pipeline to reach tidewater to reach foreign markets, they are lying. Crude oil carried by the Kinder Morgan expansion will end up as before at U.S. West Coast refineries.

Comment: The no-pay, slow pay, and partial pay, uninsured who find out they need medical care after all, drive up the costs for everyone else. Address that problem, and then there's some serious leverage to bring down average costs.  Insurance companies in Alaska struggled to deal with the former uninsurables that were brought back into the system by the PPACA. The State of Alaska addressed that problem last year with legislation, and 2017 was to be the first full year with that fix in place. We also now have the Medicaid expansion in place. In many way, the signs point to things getting better from here on out. As long as the politicians don't screw up this painfully slow progress we've made with a half baked replacement.

Just fix what is broken with the PPACA and check the partisan pride at the door.

Comment: "In addition to keeping drugs out of the wrong hands, the program helps the environment by keeping pills out of landfills and sewers, proponents say."
Stolen, misplaced, left in medicine cabinets for years creating an "attractive nuisance" -- duh! It's 2017 -- why hasn't this been thought of decades ago?
I have an older friend who has been prescribed full bottles(!) of narcotics twice in the past 4 years. She only used +/- 10 pills in total. There have been aides in & out of her house. This is typical.
I tried to dispose of the unused portion, finally ending up at the Sheriff's Dept.
I spoke with pharmacists at Safeway and Jim's. They told me that the DEA "doesn't trust" them. And they shouldn't. Employees are just as susceptible to addiction as anyone else. But why not this secure kiosk idea 20 years ago?
Really, it's basic. How many lives could have been saved?
Glad to see it, finally. It should be nationwide, immediately.
Thanks Orzias, Locke, and anyone who was instrumental.

Comment: Both sides are right. The development will bring more people, more vitality, more business. And it will bring more traffic, more congestion, more noise, more slowdowns, more accidents, and more of the other problems that increased and denser population brings. It's not simply a good growth or NIMBY issue. It's a question in the larger sense of whether this particular neighborhood is appropriate for this kind of development, given that we need some neighborhoods with less density and some with more. And it is a question of whether the people in this neighborhood are being asked to bear more than is fair in the way of having to change their lives and adapt to greater population density. I like both kinds of neighborhoods, and I believe that each has its place. Since I live south of the planned development, I really regret the time it will add to my daily travel. But that's purely selfish. I'm hoping for a compromise. Three stories.

Comment: Interesting F1 evolution !

The 1000HP figure is due to the electric motors - independent of the engine which merely keeps the batteries charged. Even then the 1000 HP figure is only instantaneous during maximum acceleration - a feature intrinsic of electric traction ( DC ) motors. The issue as always with electric vehicles is battery capacity and life expectancy - but methinks a toned down version ( e.g. like the Chevy Volt ) will be the long term practical solution. 

Most of current IC vehicles are grossly over powered in order to obtain acceptable acceleration - not to maintain the usual cruising speeds. Smaller high efficiency IC engines ( constant speed ) and batteries for acceleration are in my mind the future - not the pure battery powered heavily subsidized greenie day dreams  that get sucked in and stuck in the air cleaner of my 1/2 Ton .......    .-)

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: Joseph Conrad wrote of a "shadow line" between the passing of one world and the arrival of another, a place where glimpses of the old were increasingly difficult, soon to be eclipsed. I wonder if this is where indigenous peoples see themselves, on the shadow line, staring at the void of a world soon to be lost.

In the novels of William Faulkner, one effect on the reader is in understanding that what Faulkner created was a mythology of disappearance, the slow dying out of a way of life in the old South. Faulkner bequeathed to us this vivid depiction of backwoods southern life, where everyone has mule trouble, where every wagon was broken, because he knew it, lived it.

It is intersection of these things, the shadow line, the mythology of disappearance, the struggles to assert identity encountered on the other side of them, that leads me to think that indigenous people have a point, that it is really theirs to bridge these gaps, merging the identities of the old and the new.

Comment: JB is right; climate change can have some pretty dramatic effects.  Since the pass of the Last Glacial Maximum, sea levels have risen over 100 m, drowning immense areas of low-lying tropical rainforests in SE Asia, cutting off Britain from the rest of Europe, submerging island habitats beneath the waves.  In the meantime, changes in rainfall and snowfall transformed huge swathes of the American West from a fruitful terrane of lakes and meadows and streams to a semi-arid wasteland - leading to the demise of hundreds of species of iconic mammals, birds, and fish.  (Haven't seen a mastodon or a giant ground sloth lately, have you??)  Similarly, North Africa went from a verdant land of rivers, woods, and grasslands, populated by people and magnificent African game, to the world's largest desert.

*And the Democratic Party didn't do a damn thing to stop it!*

It's true!  :)   (Man, that sure determines how *I'm* going to vote!)

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: I saw a travelling Shakespeare company that came to our high school in the early 60s with a striking Eskimo dress/set version of Lear.  It was so appropriate to the elemental story and characters of Lear. (though god knows how they withstood wearing furs under lights.)

As years went by, the memory of it stayed with me, though not the names.  I thought it was a travelling company from the Stratford Festival. Maybe 10 years ago, I saw a brief reference to it in Toronto's Alumnae Theatre, in a tribute to Herbert Whittaker, who had designed it (not that I would have known that at the time.)  I was then able to find it on the internet: Canadian Players was the company, and actors included Mervyn Blake and William Hutt.

So, good luck continuing to track down your mystery.

Comment: Not quite.
There is no valid 'service dog identification', so not seeing any 'service dog identification' means absolutely nothing.
And Federal law does not prohibit dogs in shopping carts.
www.ada.gov/regs2010/service_animal_qa.html
Specifically Q 31, which states:
"Q31. Are stores required to allow service animals to be placed in a shopping cart?
A. Generally, the dog must stay on the floor, or the person must carry the dog.  For example, if a person with diabetes has a glucose alert dog, he may carry the dog in a chest pack so it can be close to his face to allow the dog to smell his breath to alert him of a change in glucose levels."
Nothing in there about 'prohibited'. The cart is the property of the store, and if the store allows the dog in the cart, the dog can be in the cart. Likewise, if the store says 'no dogs in cart', the dog must be removed.
Please review the laws which apply.

Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: Great initiative.  In BC, the $30/tonne levy on carbon emissions gets returned to taxpayers as reduced income and corporate taxes.  I estimate that I as well as a majority of British Columbians are better off financially because of the levy.  I can't wait for it to go to $100/tonne or even higher. Comment: Question. 
Serious Question.
When a kingdom "dissolves"  What is the process ?  Do they file papers in some international court ? "Hey, we are done, filing bankruptcy, closing down..."  
Do thy have to file paperwork and merge with another governing entity ? Transfer assets ?  Do they have to notify their population, "Our government does not exist any more, you are now subjects of this other entity or you can join up with anyone else you want."  

Seriously, what is the process to dissolve a kingdom ?
Then, was any of that process ever completed with the "Kingdom" of Hawaii ?
I put Kingdom in quotes because a Kingdom is separate from the physical property it occupies.
There are documented cases right now of nations without those nations having their own physical property. It is called a "Stateless Nation"
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stateless_nation

This is what the Kingdom of Hawaii has been equated to, and in fact is shown in the list on that page.

Comment: I have, for a long time, supported all measures of transparency in disclosing of trailer fees. However, I definitely do not support the banning of them.

The decision as to how mutual fund clients will pay their advisors should be the clients decision.

I have asked more than half of my clients whether they would prefer to pa me by invoice rather than the current trailer fee arrangement. To date, not one has indicated a preference to pay by invoice.

If the clients aren't in favor of this ban, then who is being served by this disruption?

The regulators know very well that smaller clients (anyone with less than $50,000 accounts) will simply be kicked to the curb in a fee for service model. These people frequently need the most advice on savings, debt service, and insurance products. 

This development is being driven by the banks, They have lost a lot of business to advisors who offer customized service to their clients and they are exerting influence on the regulators to get it back.

Comment: The annual Water Quality Report of the Board of Water Supply is something I get every year from them, just to keep an eye on the testing  results they get. Going through old papers, I found 2010's.  I got 2016's  recently. We have water from wells in Kahuku, Hau'ula  and Punalu'u that did test positive for nitrate in the water in 2016. It was not there in 2010. Usually this is the result of pesticides...and can cause illness and death in infants if in higher concentrations than the 'average' ppm quantity found  in their 2016 samples; however this amount can spike quickly in well water near the nitrate sources.  More research on this is needed probably 'just because' ...   Sources of nitrate in our water can exist other than pesticides; but they aren't good for us either - sewage related things. If anyone cares to get real on the SCIENCE  of pesticide BEFORE we have 'blue babies' born from nitrate contamination of water, the time is ticking away now.

Comment: This is potentially bad news for Canada. If Trump and his cabinet decide to migrate social policy away from federally run transfer payments, then taxes go down. If taxes go down, presumably competitiveness goes up (at the expense of social benefit recipients, of course), and if competitiveness goes up, then that pressures our programs.  I think at this point, the best thing we can do is continue to pursue opportunities on the EurAsian continent and continue reducing the amount of trade we do with the US.

The other thing I think Trump needs to address is wages, as they exist today, not only in the US, but, by extension, Canada and every other trading partner. The fact is that even though productivity has increased 100% in the last 30 years, wages have decreased by 10% and benefits by a lot more, in some cases, benefits have been totally smashed. I think he and his billionaire friends need to make a sincere effort to rectify this situation by producing the money. Don't hold your breath.

Comment: The 1-game play-in is a monstrosity.  It might work in NCAA, the Olympics, or the NFL, but for a league that features a 162-game sked, and is so pitcher-dependent, to have a 1-game winner-take-all playoff is no good.  Makes a mockery of the entire season that some barely .500 team could steal the 1-game play-in, then get hot and get to the WS.  They shouldn't be even allowed in.  The 2nd WC team is a diversion, to create some excitement, the illusion of a race to make the post-season for also-ran teams.  

I get the 1st WC team, there could be a team finishing 2nd in its division with a better record than a team that won its divisio.  You can make a case for 1 WC team, but not 2.

Comment: The BATF in 2015 considered banning certain types of 5.56 X 45 ammunition, currently used by all our armed forces in M16 service rifles and their military and civilian variants. The armor-piercing round under consideration was the M855 "green tip" ammunition used primarily by the marine corps and at least until recently available for purchase by civilians. I don't know what happened with that ban, whether it went into effect or not. To my knowledge hunting ammunition isn't under consideration for a ban, though I think most high-powered hunting bullets would penetrate Kevlar armor.

Game hunting has many advocates among sports retailers, guides, the tourist industry, and wildlife management agencies. Big game bullets are carefully engineered and manufactured to kill quickly, and those characteristics make them able to penetrate heavy bone while deforming in a controlled manner. The point is, that design is crucial to relatively humane hunting.

Comment: - not my words, but these are: if you believe The Free Market deserves ultimate deference in any consideration of regulations in wages in the context of a working class, then I'd put forward the possibility that you're not yet aware of the extent to which our market is not at all Free - at least not in the way you'd perhaps presume freedom to be defined. That is, here in 2017 our government, through a majority of citizens' consent  implied by an elected political class, undertakes by policy to introduce and exercise controls in all fields and spheres, particularly with regards to economics and finance. Examination of total implications in a policy like Quantitative Easing for example, should reasonably result in a conclusion that the Free Market is not free in any traditional ideal sense. The market was "freer" before the Great Depression than after it, leading many to - for the first time - acknowledge a  manifestation of freedom that was evidently to its own effective detriment.

Comment: Good. It seems to me that we are close to "peak air traffic." As with so many other things, it means getting air traffic infrastructure to new places, whether it can be done under the terms of conventional safety or not. So it is very good that orbital systems can situate the locating functions so well.

I'm enjoying Guy Murchie's book, "Song of the Sky" again after several decades. He wrote it in the early 1950s as an air navigator and it's an absolutely superb telling of the needs of locating oneself and the part of the planet that is between sea level and the stratosphere. It makes me want to go out and buy a sextant, and learn how to use it!

Comment: "...a Halloween costume crisis."

On some level, I believe our whole society functions on "crisis" mode--but sometimes we really lose sight of what a real crisis is.  Murdered and missing women?  Not when74% of the murdered and missing indigenous are men; Oh, and the west coast opiod OD "crisis."?  Now, wait: I'm not comparing loss of life with the loss of Halloween costume choice, but...well, heck, B.C. (population 4.6 million) just might rack up 1,500 OD deaths by the end of the year. Crisis?  Well, yeah, if numbers mean anything, but not the O.D.s.  The REAL health crisis is cancer deaths: close to 10,000 in 2015 alone.  Heart disease: over 6,000. Stroke deaths: another 6,000. In one year!

A real Vancouver health crisis occurred between June 1918-June 1919. Only 1,174 died from this one disease--the Spanish flu. Back in the day, that represented 1% of the city's population. In today's terms: 46,000.

We've got plenty of real crisis...If we only can figure out what they are.

Comment: I agree that mastery of first-year university math would be a better minimum test for specialist teachers of primary/junior math or anyone teaching math in gr. 7-8. Poland is one country that requires specialist math teachers beyond gr. 3. Korea also has many specialized primary math teachers, and the university math courses required are similar to what you've outlined, minus the computer science. In most countries, including top performers on international math tests such as Singapore, teachers up to gr. 6 are usually generalists. Singapore requires mastery of elementary and HS math content (demonstrated in a written test) as a precondition for entry to a primary-junior teacher education program. If Canadian schools of education would move to that requirement and better courses in their programs regarding pedagogical content knowledge in math (i.e., how to teach the content, such as is done in Japan, Korea and Singapore), it would be a great improvement on the present situation.

Comment: And what would be the point of complaining just because this time we lost?  Changing the EC won't change the outcome of this election.  I was against the EC before the election because (1) it distorts the campaign, with only a few "swing" states actively contested - exactly what makes the issues of Florida the most important issues for the country as a whole?  (2) it disenfranchises minority opinion in a state, either red or blue, (3) it allows for an outcome where the popular vote and the EC vote don't coincide - which is a terrible situation for a democracy.  Like most people I thought Clinton would win the popular vote.  Unlike most people, however, I thought it was possible, because of Clinton's unpopularity, that there would be many more 3rd party voters, and that it was possible that Clinton would win the EC and Trump would win a plurality of the popular vote, and given the rhetoric from the Trump campaign about rigged elections, there might even be bloodshed.

Comment: Just because Hydro claims Site C's power is inexpensive doesn't make it so.  Don't be fooled by the "free" water.   Nat. gas would have been far cheaper.  Calgary recently built a gas power plant for $1.4 billion that produces more energy (6,500 GWh/yr) than Site C.   The annual fuel cost is a fraction of the yearly interest paid on a $10 billion loan.

By example, would you buy a $250,000 car that ran on water and lasts 100 years instead of a $25,000 car that burned gas and lasts 20 years?  Especially if the gas cost $2,000/yr but the interest on a $250,000 loan was $10,000/yr?  And what if I told you the $250 K car may end up costing $400 K, but when you find this out you'll be on the hook for $100 K which you won't get back.  And that it will take you 70 years to pay off the $250 K car, but changing technology will make the car obsolete in 20 years.   How stupid Hydro's Site C financial justification is.  Just ask Newfoundland about the disastrous Muskrat Falls hydro project.

Comment: "Um who says that study is the consensus?"

The international scientific community.  The IPCC is, literally, the scientific consensus on climate change.

"On that basis, it is reassuring to note that nearly every major national scientific body e.g. the Royal Society (UK) or the National Academy of Sciences (US), unreservedly supports the work and findings of the IPCC. An expanded list can be found here, including this statement:"

https://www.skepticalscience.com/Hulme-IPCC-consensus.htm

"A just published study predicts 4 million Americans along the coast are at risk."

This is known as "single-study syndrome."  Single studies do not form a consensus, and they certainly don't overturn one.

Comment: Even though Rolo may not be the highest paid, UH spends  way more money on the athletic department than they do on the medical school.  And yet, we here have a serious shortage of
doctors in almost every speciality and the shortage is critical especially on the neighbor islands.
UH has had at various times fairly good football teams but it will never ever become comparable
to football programs like USC, Alabama, LSU and many others who are at a another level.
The priorities here seem very out of balance with what is really important.

Comment: There are surprisingly few comments about JT's letter demanding that the number of incarcerated aboriginals be reduced. 

It should alarm everyone that our PM is telling the Justice system to make sure that less people of a specific group be sent to jail regardless of the crime rate in that group.

What message does that send?

Once again when this subject is being discussed, native leaders are offering no solution to the obvious fact that their people are committing serious crime in numbers that dwarf their portion of the population.

Lobbying governments to change how we apply the criminal code is far worse than just weak leadership. It is plain negligent.

You are getting paid to lead! So get to it!
